newsitem.title: USA: US DLA proposes changes to negotiated cobalt sale. [CORRECTED 19:11 GMT]
newsitem.headline: US DLA proposes changes to negotiated cobalt sale. [CORRECTED 19:11 GMT]

text.p: The U.S. Defense Logistics Agency is proposing key changes in the rules governing the negotiated sale of cobalt, an agency spokesman said.
The procedure for bidding and a contentious preference for domestic consumers were among the proposed changes to the negotiated sale, the first since March.
The sale of 1.5 million lbs (corrects from 1/5 million tons) is tentatively scheduled for Aug 29. The agency is planning an industry meeting on July 31 to discuss the changes.
According to a draft solicitation, DLA is proposing that the bidding price be based on an average price of 99.3 percent cobalt over a four-week period prior to the bidder's request for shipment.
In the last solicitation in March, those terms were subject to negotiation between the potential bidders and DLA.

It was those negotiations that were the bone of contention when Minor Metals Inc filed a lawsuit against DLA in U.S. District Court of Northern Virginia in May. At the time, the trading company believed it was cheated out of 1.1 million lbs. The court dismissed the suit.
The new solicitation removes the domestic preference provision which allowed domestic consumers the right of first refusal over bidders that want the option to export.
The new solicitation also provides an independent surveyor of the cobalt grades. It also defines terms for removal of the cobalt from the DLA stockpile.

"What this does is adds a bit of transparancy to the negotiated sales," said one cobalt merchant. "There was a real fear that the negotiated sales could be manipulated. It's still not as transparent as the sealed bid. But it's an improvement."
((Derek J. Caney, New York Commodity Desk, 212-859-1640))
